meanings.definition: To make something free from bacteria or other microorganisms.
meanings.sent1: I always sterilise my hands before eating to keep away germs.
meanings.sent2: The hospital staff sterilise the medical equipment to prevent infections.
meanings.sent3: The chef decided to sterilise the kitchen after finding a bug in the flour.
meanings.sent4: Her smile could sterilise any doubts in his mind.
meanings.sent5: The sunlight seemed to sterilise the room, making it feel fresh and clean.

meanings.definition: To make someone unable to produce offspring.
meanings.sent1: The veterinarian recommended sterilising the stray cat to control the population.
meanings.sent2: Some animal shelters sterilise pets before adoption to prevent overpopulation.
meanings.sent3: The magician's wand seemed to sterilise the rabbit, much to the audience's surprise.
meanings.sent4: The decision to move to a new city seemed to sterilise her dreams of having a big family.
meanings.sent5: The potion had the power to sterilise any creature that drank it.

meanings.definition: To make something free from living organisms.
meanings.sent1: The farmer needed to sterilise the soil before planting new crops.
meanings.sent2: The laboratory technician sterilised the petri dishes to ensure accurate results.
meanings.sent3: The robot was programmed to sterilise the entire spaceship before the crew arrived.
meanings.sent4: His words seemed to sterilise the room, leaving everyone speechless.
meanings.sent5: The cleaning solution was strong enough to sterilise even the toughest stains.
